THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO DEMONSTRATE, BY A COMBINATION OF LABORATORY AND FIELD RESEARCH, THAT A SIMPLE, INEXPENSIVE TIME-INTEGRATED, BIOFILM-BASED SURFACE CAN SUCCESSFULLY CAPTURE CRYPTOSPORIDIUM OOCYSTS IN RURAL ENVIRONMENTS WITH A DIVERSE SET OF POINT AND NON- POINT SOURCES OF HUMAN FECAL CONTAMINATION. RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO TEST THE EFFICACY OF INCREASED CALCIUM ION CONCENTRATIONS TO ENHANCE OOCYST CAPTURE.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO DRASTICALLY SIMPLIFY BIOGAS UPGRADING USING ADSORBENT MATERIALS ENGINEERED SPECIFICALLY TO PRODUCE GRID QUALITY BIOMETHANE. THIS INNOVATIVE COST-EFFECTIVE TECHNOLOGY IS COMPRISED OF CONCURRENT REMOVAL OF CARBON DIOXIDE, HYDROGEN SULFIDE AND WATER VAPOR FROM THE FEED GAS, FOLLOWED BY ADSORBENT REGENERATION AND COOLING IN AIR BEFORE STARTING THE SUBSEQUENT CYCLE.

THE AIM OF THE PROJECT IS TO USE A SONICATION REACTOR TO EFFICIENTLY REMEDIATE PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS)-CONTAMINATED SITES THROUGH SONIC DEGRADATION TO REDUCE HUMAN AND ANIMAL EXPOSURE TO PFASS. SPECIFICALLY, THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL DESIGN A NOVEL ULTRASOUND DELIVERY METHOD TO GENERATE ACOUSTIC CAVITATION WHICH COMBINES A LOW FREQUENCY PROBE TRANSDUCER AND A HIGH FREQUENCY SUBMERSIBLE TRANSDUCER TO CREATE AN INTENSE ULTRASONIC FIELD THAT STIRS UP SOLIDS IN SOLUTION AND INDUCE CAVITATION.

THIS PROJECT INTRODUCES A GREEN APPROACH TO PRODUCE HEMPCRETE ' A RENEWABLE AND NATURAL BUILDING MATERIAL WITH UNIQUE ADVANTAGES OVER EXISTING MATERIALS. BUILDINGS MADE FROM HEMPCRETE SHOW REDUCED ENERGY CONSUMPTION, HOWEVER TRADITIONAL METHODS OF PRODUCING HEMPCRETE RELEASE TOXIC WASTE. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE AN ADVANCED GREEN PULPING METHOD TO PRODUCE HEMP FIBER FOR CONSTRUCTION WITHOUT ANY TOXIC WASTE STREAMS. THE PROJECT WILL DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF HEMPCRETE'S PROPERTIES IN REAL WORLD SETTINGS AND STUDY OPTIMIZATION TO MAXIMIZE THE AMOUNT OF FIBERS THAT CAN BE PROCESSED.

THIS PROJECT WILL CHARACTERIZE THE LOCATIONS, SCOPE, AND IMPACTS OF STRAIGHT PIPES IN RURAL ALABAMA. MANY HOUSEHOLDS IN THIS AREA HAVE NO ACCESS TO PUBLIC SEWERS AND NO AFFORDABLE OPTIONS TO TREAT THEIR WASTEWATER. IN THESE CONDITIONS, STRAIGHT PIPES OFTEN ILLICITLY DISCHARGE UNTREATED WASTEWATER ONTO THE GROUND. THIS HAS POTENTIAL FOR SUBSTANTIAL ADVERSE IMPACTS ON HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT. THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE A MODEL THAT CAN QUANTIFY THE EXTENT OF THE STRAIGHT PIPE PROBLEM, ENABLING COMMUNITY AND COUNTY-SCALE WASTEWATER MANAGEMENT PLANS TO BE DEVELOPED AND THE HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS TO BE ACCURATELY ASSESSED..

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A NOVEL, COST-EFFECTIVE, ENVIRONMENTALLY-FRIENDLY PHOTOCATALYTIC METHOD TO REMOVE AND DEGRADE PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN RECLAIMED WASTEWATER EFFLUENT (WE). WE RECLAMATION FOR REUSE IN AGRICULTURE HAS BEEN PRACTICED BY MANY REGIONS THAT LACK SUFFICIENT FRESHWATER SUPPLIES FOR IRRIGATION ' A SUSTAINABLE STRATEGY TO MEET WATER DEMANDS. HOWEVER, CURRENT TECHNOLOGIES FOR WE REUSE IN AGRICULTURE ARE CHALLENGED BY THE PRESENCE OF EMERGING ORGANIC CONTAMINANTS (I.E. PFAS), WHICH BRING ADVERSE IMPACTS ON CROPS, SOIL, ECOSYSTEMS, AND HUMAN HEALTH.

THE CONCERN FOR LEAD CONTAMINATION, EVEN IN SMALL CONCENTRATIONS, HAS LED TO THE NEED FOR AN ANALYTICAL METHOD THAT CAN RAPIDLY DETERMINE TRACE LEVELS. CURRENT METHODS USED TO DETERMINE LEAD LEVELS REQUIRE TRANSPORTATION OF THE SAMPLE TO A LABORATORY, TRAINED PERSONNEL, AND THE USE OF MERCURY: A HIGHLY TOXIC, NONBIODEGRADABLE HEAVY METAL. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A BIOPOLYMER SENSOR THAT CAN DETERMINE TRACE LEVELS OF LEAD AT THE TERMINAL PLUMBING SOURCE (I.E., FAUCETS). THIS SENSOR WILL BE LOW-COST, SIMPLE, AND PORTABLE COMPARED TO CONVENTIONAL METHODS OF DETECTING LEAD CONTAMINATION.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A GREEN CHEMICAL PROCESS INVOLVING THE FORMATION OF REACTIVE NANOBUBBLES (NBS) TO CONTROL HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS) AND REMOVE CYANOTOXINS. THE OCCURRENCE OF HABS IS INCREASINGLY COMMON IN INLAND FRESHWATER IN THE U.S. AND NEGATIVELY AFFECT THE ENVIRONMENT, ECOSYSTEMS, AND HUMAN HEALTH. OZONE NBS PROMOTE RAPID OXIDATION AND DECOMPOSITION OF ORGANIC WATER POLLUTANTS AND ALGAL BIOMASS, WHILE LEAVING NO CHEMICAL RESIDUES OR DISINFECTION BYPRODUCTS AND THUS HAVING NEGLIGIBLE IMPACTS ON WATER QUALITY OR AQUATIC LIFE.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A RENEWABLE TREATMENT STRATEGY TO REMOVE TRACE LEVELS OF ARSENIC FROM DRINKING WATER. THE STRATEGY CENTERS ON NATURALLY OCCURRING PROTEINS FOUND IN BACTERIA THAT CAN TRAP ARSENIC FROM WATER AS A MEANS OF PROTECTION. AFTER REDUCING ARSENIC CONCENTRATIONS, THE BACTERIA CAN BE REMOVED FROM THE WATER SOURCE USING MAGNETS. USING BIOLOGICAL MATERIALS FOR ARSENIC REMOVAL IS MORE SUSTAINABLE AND SELECTIVE THAN CURRENT TECHNOLOGIES. THE REMEDIATION STRATEGY AIMS TO BE INEXPENSIVE, WITH MINIMAL POWER REQUIREMENTS AND NO COMPLICATED EQUIPMENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP ELECTRICITY-FREE WATER TREATMENT TECHNOLOGY IN ORDER TO PRODUCE CLEANER WATER WITH LOWER CAPITAL AND OPERATING COSTS THAN CONVENTIONAL TREATMENT PLANTS. THE PLANT USES A VERTICAL-FLOW, WASTE-FREE RAM PUMP TO LIFT TREATED WATER TO THE TOP OF THE PLANT, IMPROVING EFFICIENCY, ELIMINATING THE NEED FOR MECHANICAL CONTROLS, AND REDUCING THE OCCURRENCE OF MECHANICAL FAILURE. THIS NOVEL TYPE OF RAM PUMP COULD REDUCE THE COST OF INSTALLING CONVENTIONAL WATER TREATMENT TECHNOLOGY AND MAKE SAFE, CLEAN WATER MORE ACCESSIBLE TO ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP A COST-EFFECTIVE AND TECHNOLOGICALLY FEASIBLE UV-LED PHOTOCATALYTIC PROTOTYPE EMISSIONS CONTROL DEVICE THAT WOULD BE INCORPORATED INTO AN AUTOMOBILE TO REDUCE FUEL VAPOR EMISSIONS BY AT LEAST 70% COMPARED TO CURRENT EMISSIONS CONTROL SYSTEMS. UV-LEDS ARE SMALL, ROBUST LIGHT SOURCES THAT REQUIRE LOW DIRECT CURRENT POWER THAT CAN BE PROVIDED BY THE EXISTING AUTOMOBILE BATTERY. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT AN ECONOMIC ANALYSIS AND DESIGN EDUCATIONAL AND MARKETING TOOLS FOR THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DESIGN AND FABRICATE A NOVEL NON-THERMAL PLASMA (NTP) SYSTEM TO REMOVE SILOXANE FROM LANDFILL GAS (LFG). THE SYSTEM IS CALLED CLEAN, RENEWED UPGRADED LFG (CLNERG) AND IS A TREATMENT METHOD FOR PURIFYING LANDFILL GAS PRIOR TO ITS COMBUSTION. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SUSTAINABLE SOURCES OF ENERGY WHILE IMPROVING AIR QUALITY BY PREVENTING AND CONTROLLING AIR POLLUTION FROM MULTI-POLLUTANTS AS WELL AS ADDRESSING RESOURCE RECOVERY IN THE ENERGY SECTOR.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP SOLAR POWERED, LOW-COST, LONG-LIFETIME AIR QUALITY SENSORS THAT CAN BE CALIBRATED WITH AN EPA REFERENCE MONITOR USING MACHINE LEARNING, DISTRIBUTED AT A COMMUNITY SCALE AND CAN PROVIDE RELIABLE, OPEN-SOURCE AIR QUALITY DATA TO THE PUBLIC IN REAL TIME THROUGH A LONG-RANGE WIRELESS AREA NETWORK. NASA BIAS DETECTION TECHNOLOGY WILL BE USED TO DETECT SENSOR RELIABILITY. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE LOCAL COMMUNITIES WITH THE ABILITY TO MONITOR THEIR OWN AIR QUALITY AND PROVIDE SCIENTIFICALLY USEFUL AIR MONITORING DATA.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A MORE EFFICIENT LUMINESCENT SOLAR CONCENTRATOR (LSC) USING A COMBINATION OF TWO DIFFERENT QUANTUM DOT MATERIALS FREE OF HEAVY METALS. THIS WOULD BE A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO POLLUTION PREVENTION, AS IT WOULD PROVIDE A VIABLE AND COST-EFFECTIVE PATHWAY TO PROVIDING CLEAN SOLAR POWER TO MEET U.S. ELECTRIC POWER NEEDS. IF VIABLE, THIS PROCESS COULD BE THE FIRST TIME A SPECIFIC TYPE OF ENERGY TRANSFER BETWEEN QUANTUM DOTS WOULD BE USED TO IMPROVE ON THE EFFICIENCY OF LUMINESCENT SOLAR CONCENTRATORS.

CYANOTOXINS, INCLUDING MICROCYSTIN, FROM CYANOBACTERIAL ALGAL BLOOMS IN SURFACE WATER CAN BE VERY HARMFUL, THREATENING DRINKING, IRRIGATION AND RECREATIONAL WATER SAFETY AND HUMAN HEALTH, AND CONVENTIONAL WATER TREATMENT CANNOT EFFECTIVELY REMOVE THEM. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP AN ADSORPTION AND OXIDATION-DRIVEN REGENERATION PROCESS USING A NOVEL MULTIFUNCTIONAL BIOCHAR (MFB) TO EFFECTIVELY REMOVE MICROCYSTIN FROM DRINKING WATER SOURCES. THE MFB WILL BE PRODUCED FROM AGRICULTURAL WASTES VIA A SIMPLER, MORE ECONOMICAL AND ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY PROCESS THAN CURRENT METHODS.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A PORTABLE, LOW COST BIOFILTER THAT REMOVES FRESHWATER HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOM (FHAB) DERIVED CYANOTOXINS AND HEAVY METAL IONS FROM WATER. THE NEW APPROACH USES NANOPARTICLE (NP) EMBEDDED IN A SOY PROTEIN DERIVED CELLULOSE FILTER THAT IS BIOCOMPATIBLE, BIODEGRADABLE AND INEXPENSIVE. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC HEALTH BY PROVIDING SAFE AND CLEAN WATER. THE PROPOSED FILTER WILL DELIVER IMPROVED EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY IN REMOVING CYANOTOXINS FROM FHAB CONTAMINATED SOURCE WATERS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A GREEN, SUSTAINABLE AND ECO-FRIENDLY MEMBRANE SYSTEM THAT REMOVES CHEMICALS THAT PERSIST FOLLOWING TRADITIONAL WATER TREATMENT. TO ACHIEVE THIS, A CELLULOSE NANOSCALE ANION-EXCHANGE RESIN WILL BE DEVELOPED. SINCE CELLULOSE NANOFIBERS ARE ABUNDANT AND INEXPENSIVE, THIS PROPOSAL, IF SUCCESSFUL, WILL PROVIDE AFFORDABLE WATER PURIFICATION SOLUTIONS TO RURAL COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF CONTAMINANTS FOUND IN WATER SYSTEMS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A HIGH-THROUGHPUT SYSTEM TO REMOVE ARSENIC (AS), A CARCINOGEN, FROM CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER TO MEET THE WATER DEMANDS OF RURAL CALIFORNIA COMMUNITIES. THE SYSTEM WILL USE AIR CATHODE ASSISTED IRON ELECTROCOAGULATION (ACAIE), WHICH OXIDIZES AS TO MAKE IT EASIER TO REMOVE. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DESIGN A SYSTEM TO PROCESS LARGE VOLUMES OF HIGHLY CONTAMINATED WATER AND LOWER THE AS LEVEL BELOW THE EPA MAXIMUM CONTAMINANT LEVEL (MCL).

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE A LOW-COST SELF-SUSTAINABLE PORTABLE DESALINATION SYSTEM THAT USES A WAVE-AND-SOLAR RENEWABLE ENERGY TO SUPPLY FRESH WATER COMMUNITIES THAT LACK A SAFE AND SUSTAINABLE SUPPLY. THE FUNCTIONAL PROTOTYPE HAS A 65L/DAY DESALINATION CAPACITY INTEGRATED WITH WAVE AND SOLAR HYBRID ENERGY, WHICH IS THE BASIC DAILY FRESH WATER CONSUMPTION PER CAPITAL. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SAFE AND STABLE FRESH WATER AND REDUCE ENVIRONMENTAL POLLUTION AT LOW COST USING RENEWABLE ENERGY.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A POINT-OF-USE (POU) POUR-THROUGH TREATMENT SYSTEM PROTOTYPE FILTER TO TREAT LEAD AND POLYCHLORINATED BIPHENYLS (PCBS) IN DRINKING WATER. THE LOW-COST FILTER WILL BE MADE OF LOCALLY-SOURCED BIOMASS AND GEOMATERIALS IN MIXED-MEDIA BENEFITING COMMUNITIES WHO LACK BASIC WATER AND SEWAGE SERVICES. THIS TECHNOLOGY WILL PROVIDE USERS AN ALTERNATIVE TO EXPENSIVE COMMERCIAL WATER FILTER SYSTEMS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A SIMPLE AND INEXPENSIVE PAPER TEST FOR LEAD IN TAP WATER USING A PROBE ENCAPSULATED BY POLYMER NANOPARTICLES THAT HAS A COLORIMETRIC RESPONSE TO LEAD. SIGNAL CAN BE SEEN VISUALLY. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE ABILITY TO ACCURATELY TEST FOR LEAD IN TAP WATER. CURRENTLY, LEAD TESTING IS EXPENSIVE AND REQUIRES TRAINED PERSONNEL TO PERFORM THE TEST. WITH THIS ASSAY, HOMEOWNERS AND COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING DISADVANTAGED CAN VISUALLY DETECT THE PRESENCE OF LEAD IN THEIR WATER THUS ALLOWING THEM TO MAKE DECISIONS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A FIELD-DEPLOYABLE DROPLET DIGITAL POLYMERASE CHAIN REACTION (DDPCR) SYSTEM THAT CAN RAPIDLY DETECT PATHOGENIC ESCHERICHIA COLI (E. COLI) IN WATER. THE PROJECT WILL USE THE PROPOSED SYSTEM TO TEST THE WATER SAMPLES OF THE ANIMAS RIVER AND THE BEAR CREEK IN COLORADO, AND THE RESEARCHERS PLAN TO EDUCATE LOCAL COMMUNITIES (INCLUDING NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES) IN THE FOUR-CORNER AREA ON THE IMPORTANCE OF WATER RESOURCE PROTECTION AND TECHNOLOGIES FOR ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION. IF SUCCESSFUL, THIS PROJECT WOULD BE A GREAT IMPROVEMENT OVER EXISTING METHODS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DESIGN AND TEST A POLLUTION CONTROL STRATEGY FOR NONPOINT NUTRIENT SOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL CREATE A SYSTEM TO CONVERT ORGANIC MATTER IN AGRICULTURAL RUNOFF TO HYDROGEN PEROXIDE MITIGATING THE GROWTH OF CYANOBACTERIA HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOM (CHAB). A CONSTRUCTED WETLAND WILL BE DEVELOPED TO MITIGATE EMISSIONS. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AT A LOW COST AND PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A DRYWALL SUBSTITUTE TO REPLACE TRADITIONAL GYPSUM-BASED DRYWALL. A TWO-STEP PROCESS WILL BE USED TO CONVERT WHEAT STRAW INTO A CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL THAT WILL HAVE COMPARABLE MECHANICAL, THERMAL, AND CHEMICAL PROPERTIES BUT SUPERIOR IN MOISTURE RESISTANCE, WORKABILITY AND BIODEGRADABILITY UPON DISPOSAL. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH BY REDUCING THE AMOUNT OF SOLID WASTE DISCARDED IN LANDFILLS FROM CROP WASTE AND CONSTRUCTION/DEMOLITION WASTE.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DESIGN A SIDEWALK THAT CAN BE BUILT USING RECYCLED AND LESS ENERGY- AND CARBON-INTENSIVE MATERIALS WITH THE THINNEST POSSIBLE THICKNESS, TO REDUCE MATERIAL USE AND LIMIT HEAT STORAGE CAPACITY. THIS COULD INCLUDE RECYCLED MATERIALS, USE OF FIBERS SUCH AS SYNTHETIC TEXTILES AND 3-D CONCRETE PRINTING. BY REVISITING THE MATERIALS AND TECHNIQUES THAT CITIES AND TOWNS USE TO BUILD SIDEWALKS, THIS PROJECT COULD IDENTIFY DURABLE, ENVIRONMENTALLY SUSTAINABLE AND COST-EFFECTIVE APPROACHES TO REDUCE POLLUTION ASSOCIATED WITH SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP AN INEXPENSIVE, SCALABLE AND RECYCLABLE WATER- AND OIL- RESISTANT PAPER. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO REDUCE THE LOSS OF PULP AND THE IMPACT TO THE ENVIRONMENT, REDUCE THE ENERGY AND WATER USED TO GENERATE NEW PULP, AND ELIMINATE THE NEED FOR UNFRIENDLY PAPER COATINGS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A PRACTICAL AND COST-EFFECTIVE APPROACH TO TREAT PER- AND POLY FLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN DRINKING WATER IN HOMES USING FUNCTIONALIZED SAWDUST BIOMASS. CELLULOSE-BASED SAWDUST WOULD REPLACE MORE EXPENSIVE METHODS SUCH AS ACTIVATED CARBON WHICH WILL PROVIDE A MORE AFFORDABLE SOLUTION TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH BY REMOVING PFAS FROM DRINKING WATER.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP NOVEL LOW-COST BIO-HYBRID ABSORBENTS FOR POINT-OF-USE (POU) TREATMENT OF PER- AND POLY FLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN HOMES AND OFFICES. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH BY IMPROVING REMOVAL EFFICIENCY OF PFAS POLLUTANTS AND PROVIDING ACCESS TO SAFE DRINKING WATER FOR COMMUNITIES, ESPECIALLY THOSE WITH THE GREATEST NEED.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP AN ELECTRICALLY CHARGED GRANULAR ACTIVATED CARBON (GAC) POINT-OF-USE (POU) DEVICE TO INCREASE THE ADSORPTION/DESORPTION CAPACITY OF PER- AND POLY FLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) FROM DRINKING WATER. IF SUCCESSFUL, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE FIRST EVIDENCE OF THE REMOVAL EFFICIENCY OF THIS TECHNOLOGY AND PROVIDE RURAL COMMUNITIES AND HOMEOWNERS AN OPTION TO TREAT CONTAMINATED PFAS WATER RESULTING IN CLEAN AND SAFE DRINKING WATER.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO FURTHER DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE A SIMPLE OPERATIONAL TECHNOLOGY TO REDUCE AERATION COSTS IN WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANTS (WWTPS) AND ASSESS HOW WELL THE TECHNOLOGY REDUCES ENERGY CONSUMPTION AND GENERATED POLLUTION. THE TECHNOLOGY WILL MAKE USE OF SENSORS AND ALGORITHMS TO CONTROL OXYGEN FLUCTUATIONS TO MEET REGULATORY CONSTRAINTS WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY MINIMIZING ENERGY CONSUMPTION. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE PERFORMANCE OF WWTPS WHILE KEEPING COST AND EASE OF USE SIMPLE. (PROVIDE CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A NOVEL TWO-DIMENSIONAL (2D) MOLYBDENUM DISULPHIDE (MOS2) SPONGE OIL-WATER SEPARATOR (MDSOS) DESIGNED TO SOAK UP OIL FROM THE OCEAN, REPELLING WATER IN THE PROCESS. THE INNOVATIVE HIGH-TECH SPONGE SYSTEM IS AN IDEAL CANDIDATE FOR PROMOTING SUSTAINABILITY PRACTICES IN A COMMUNITY AND INDUSTRIES FOR OIL-WATER SEPARATION. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DO PROVIDE A TOOL THAT IMPROVES UPON TRADITIONAL OIL SPILL REMEDIATION THUS PROTECTING AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS FROM CONTAMINATION.  (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN & SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AN INEXPENSIVE CATALYTIC CONVERTER FOR SMALL OFF-ROAD ENGINES THAT WILL REDUCE EMISSION OF AIR POLLUTANTS. THE PANCERIA FOCUSES ON REDUCING THE CONCENTRATIONS OF NITROGEN OXIDE (NO), CARBON MONOXIDE (CO), VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS), AS WELL AS PARTICULATE MATTER (PM) EMITTED THROUGH VARIOUS SMALL OFF-ROAD ENGINES SUCH AS GASOLINE-POWERED GENERATORS, LAWN MOWERS, AND LEAF BLOWERS.  THIS DEVICE WILL INCLUDE THE OPTIMIZATION OF A NON-PRECIOUS METAL CATALYST, AND ENVIRONMENTALLY-FRIENDLY AND LOW-COST MATERIALS FOR CONSTRUCTION.

THIS PROJECT IS DEVELOPING A LOW-COST, REUSABLE SENSOR THAT CHANGES COLOR TO NOTIFY THE USER THAT THE WATER IS SAFE TO DRINK. THE SUBMERSIBLE SENSOR INCORPORATES AN UV-SENSITIVE DYE-BASED INDICATOR FORMULATION THAT CHANGES COLOR REVERSIBLY SO THAT THE SENSOR CAN BE REUSED DAILY. THE TEAM AIMS TO DEVELOP A SENSOR WITH COST BELOW $1, WITH REUSABILITY FOR AT LEAST ONE YEAR. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ACHIEVE SAFE DRINKING WATER AT THE HIGHEST ACCURACY AND LOW COST WHILE MINIMIZING END-USER TRAINING. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN & SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES PILOT TESTING ON THE UPFLOW ANAEROBIC SLUDGE BLANKET (UASB) REACTOR THAT TREATS 14 PERSONS-WORTH OF DOMESTIC MIXED WASTEWATER. THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE UASB IS THAT IT'S ELECTRICITY-FREE AND INCORPORATES INNOVATIONS THAT ALLOW FOR WASTEWATER DOSING TO HANDLE VARIABLE FLOWS SUCH AS THOSE IN SMALL SYSTEMS. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE AND INNOVATE WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEMS AND ULTIMATELY IMPROVE DECENTRALIZED WASTEWATER TREATMENT TECHNOLOGICALLY FOR APPLICATION IN RURAL, UNDERSERVED AND UNDERDEVELOPED COMMUNITIES. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN & SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO DEVELOP A LOW-COST, SCALABLE, AND EFFICIENT SYSTEM TO SEPARATE AND RECOVER INDIVIDUAL COMPONENTS FROM SPENT LITHIUM-ION (LI-ION) BATTERIES WITHOUT GENERATING SECONDARY WASTES. IN PHASE II, THE TEAM IS BUILDING A PROOF-OF-CONCEPT PROTOTYPE SYSTEM THAT IS CAPABLE OF PROCESSING 1 KG/H OF SPENT LI-ION BATTERIES AND PRODUCING REUSABLE CATHODE MATERIALS WITH A 90% PURITY OR GREATER. (REVITALIZE LAND & PREVENT CONTAMINATION)

THIS PROJECT INVESTIGATES THE USE OF RECYCLED GLASS AS A COMPONENT OF A UNIQUE CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL THAT CAN SERVE AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR PORTLAND CEMENT AND FLY ASH IN CONCRETE PROJECTS.  PORTLAND CEMENT PRODUCTION IS A SIGNIFICANT SOURCE OF AIR POLLUTION. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUBSTITUTE AND INCORPORATE RECYCLED GLASS INTO THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS OF CEMENT RESULTING IN THE REDUCTION OF ENERGY CONSUMPTION AND AIR POLLUTION GENERATED, AND SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL FROM THIS ACTIVITY. (IMPROVE AIR QUALITY)

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A SIMPLER AND LESS TOXIC PRE-TREATMENT PROCESS FOR PULPING HEMP FIBERS AND PROPOSES THAT THESE FIBERS THEN BE USED AS A REINFORCING AGENT IN CEMENT, REPLACING PETROLEUM-BASED CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS. THE CEMENT INDUSTRY PRODUCERS CARBON DIOXIDE, A POTENT GREENHOUSE GAS.  THE HEMPCRETE TO BE PRODUCED VIA THIS PROJECT WILL BE LIGHTER, STRONGER, AND MORE DURABLE THAN CONVENTIONAL CEMENT.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP MODULAR SYSTEMS CONSISTING OF PLANTING BEDS THAT ALLOW HOUSEHOLD URINE AND GRAYWATER, THAT WOULD OTHERWISE BE WASTED, TO BE TREATED FOR BENEFICIAL USE ON PUBLIC GREEN SPACES. THE PROJECT, SANITARY GREEN SPACE SYSTEM, WILL PROVIDE LOW-INCOME AND RURAL COMMUNITIES A COST-EFFECTIVE INFRASTRUCTURE OPTION FOR HOUSEHOLD SEWAGE REMOVAL THAT DIVERTS AND TREATS HUMAN WASTE PRODUCTS AND WILL POTENTIAL CONVERT UNUSED OUTSIDE AREAS TO USEABLE PUBLIC SPACES. (PROVIDE CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP SIMPLE AND INEXPENSIVE TECHNOLOGY TO REDUCE LEVELS OF INDOOR AND OUTDOOR AIR POLLUTANTS GENERATED BY WOOD STOVES USED IN COLD ENVIRONMENTS ACROSS THE U.S., PARTICULARLY WITHIN DISADVANTAGED NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITIES.  THE FOCUS IS TO REDUCE LEVELS OF AIR POLLUTANTS BY IMPROVING THE BURNING EFFICIENCY OF WOOD STOVES. THIS WOULD SUPPORT IMPROVING HEALTH WHILE SUPPLYING A LOW-COST HEATING SYSTEM TO RURAL LOW-INCOME FAMILIES WHO MAY NOT HAVE EASY ACCESS TO OTHER INEXPENSIVE FUEL OPTIONS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DESIGN ALTERNATIVE KITE-BASED SYSTEM FOR AERIAL MONITORING OF AIR QUALITY.  THE KITE-BASED SENSOR, KITE-BASED ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND MAPPING SYSTEMS (KEMMS) WILL ENABLE THREE-DIMENSIONAL MAPPING OF ENVIRONMENTAL AIR QUALITY METRICS. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE OF THE KEMMS TO ULTIMATELY IMPROVE AIR QUALITY MODELING DATA TO AID IN DECISION-MAKING TO MITIGATE AND AIR POLLUTION AND IMPROVE AIR QUALITY. (IMPROVE AIR QUALITY)

THE PROJECT PROPOSES TO REDUCE/ELIMINATE EVAPORATIVE FUEL VAPOR EMISSIONS FROM AUTOMOBILES USING A NOVEL UV-LED PHOTOCATALYIC PROCESS. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE AIR QUALITY AND HEALTH BY REDUCING HAZARDOUS VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS EMITTED FROM AUTOMOBILES, ESPECIALLY IN URBAN, HIGH DENSITY TRAFFIC AREAS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DESIGN AND FABRICATE A NOVEL INLINE VERTICAL PIPELINE (RAM PUMP) THAT WILL PRODUCE NO WASTE AND RETURN EXTRACTED WATER TO THE DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM RESULTING IN LESS ENERGY USE. THE VERTICAL RAM PUMP IS ESSENTIAL TO MAKING AGUACLARA WATER TREATMENT PLANTS ELECTRICITY-FREE.  THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE WATER TREATMENT PLANTS AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO SAFE DRINKING WATER TO THOSE THAT CANNOT AFFORD TRADITIONAL WATER TREATMENT PLANTS AND AFFORDABLE DRINKING WATER. (PROVIDE CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD A MODEL TO QUANTIFY THE SCOPE OF UNTREATED RAW SEWAGE DISCHARGES IN ALABAMA FOR HOUSEHOLDS THAT ARE NOT SERVED BY SEWER SYSTEM AND TREAT THEIR WASTEWATER ONSITE USING A STRAIGHT PIPE THAT RUN FROM THEIR HOME TO AN OUTSIDE TRENCH DISCHARGING RAW SEWAGE TO THE GROUND, WHICH IS ILLEGAL. AS A RESULT, DISEASES LINKED TO POOR SANITATION ARE ON THE RISE IN THIS AREA. THE MODEL WILL PROVIDE THE FIRST EVER ESTIMATE OF THE NUMBER AND LOCATION OF THESE DISCHARGES, ENABLING DECISION MAKERS THE ABILITY TO BETTER ADDRESS THE ISSUE. (PROVIDE CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE MECHANISMS AND TECHNICAL PERFORMANCE OF NEW TETRA-AMIDO MACROCYCLIC LIGANDS (TAMLS)-PEROXIDE CATALYST IN DEGRADING THE MOST COMMON CYANOTOXINS-THE MICROCYSTINS. TAMLS/PEROXIDE ARE ENVIRONMENTALLY-FRIENDLY CATALYSTS THAT CAN BREAK DOWN TOXIC CONTAMINANTS IN WATER.  THIS IS THE FIRST STEP TOWARD AN EFFICIENT NEW METHOD TO TREAT CYANOTOXIN-CONTAMINATED WATERS.  (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THE PROJECT WILL STUDY THE REMOVAL OF PFAS CHEMICALS FROM WATER USING IRON NANOPARTICLES IN THE PRESENCE OF UV/VISIBLE LIGHT, WITH AND WITHOUT OXYGEN. THIS RESEARCH FOCUSES ON IDENTIFYING A PROCESS TO REMOVE PFAS FROM WASTEWATER EFFLUENT (WE) PRIOR TO ITS REUSE IN AGRICULTURAL IRRIGATION, THEREBY RESULTING IN REDUCED IMPACTS OF PFAS ON CROPS, EXPOSED SOIL, AND GROUNDWATER/SURFACE WATER. THE PROJECT'S OBJECTIVE IS TO INVESTIGATE A POTENTIAL NEW TECHNOLOGY FOR REMOVING PFAS FROM WE FOR REUSE IN AGRICULTURE. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER, REVITALIZE LAND AND PREVENT CONTAMINATION).

THIS PROJECT WILL DESIGN AND DEVELOP A SENSOR THAT CAN DETERMINE LOW LEVELS OF LEAD AT PLUMBING SOURCES SUCH AS FAUCETS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO CHARACTERIZE AND EVALUATE OPTIMAL CONDITIONS FOR SENSOR PERFORMANCE FOR IN SITU LEAD DETECTION. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE AN ALTERNATIVE TO MERCURY-BASED SENSORS, WHICH IS A TOXIC HEAVY METAL, AND IMPROVE DRINKING WATER QUALITY AND PUBLIC HEALTH THROUGH THE USE OF THESE RAPID, ON-SITE, PORTABLE LEAD MONITORING DEVICES. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES DEVELOPING AN APPROACH TO RECLAIM WATER FROM URBAN RUNOFF USING A NOVEL POLYELECTROLYTE-BASED MULTIFUNCTIONAL FORWARD OSMOSIS MEMBRANE. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INVESTIGATE AN INTEGRATED APPROACH TO RECLAIM WATER FROM URBAN RUNOFF AND AUGMENT POTABLE WATER SUPPLIES. THIS WOULD ALLOW FOR WATER REUSE FOR NONPOTABLE APPLICATIONS. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT EXPLORES THE MOST EFFECTIVE SOIL AMENDMENTS FROM DIFFERENT WASTE MATERIALS AND INVESTIGATES A NOVEL APPLICATION TO REMOVE PHOSPHORUS AND NITROGEN FROM RUNOFF.  THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PREVENT AND MITIGATE HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS IN RECEIVING WATERS BY ADDRESSING ATTRIBUTES OF GREEN STORMWATER INFRASTRUCTURE AS A TOOL FOR PHOSPHORUS AND NITROGEN MANAGEMENT IN LANDSCAPES UPSTREAM OF RECEIVING WATERS. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY THE INFLUENCE OF VARIOUS ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS ON MICROCYSTIN PRODUCTION IN HAZARDOUS ALGAE. THE RESEARCH WILL DEMONSTRATE A MOLECULAR METHOD FOR PREDICTION AND MONITORING OF FRESHWATER HABS, AND WILL IDENTIFY EARLY WARNING INDICATORS FOR COMMUNITIES, MUNICIPALITIES AND STATES TO USE FOR PREDICTING AND PREVENTING HAB OCCURRENCES. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OFFER AN OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP APPROACHES FOR HAB PREDICTION AND MONITORING, AND GAIN GREATER INSIGHT INTO POSSIBLE MOLECULAR LEVEL APPROACHES FOR HAB MITIGATION. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER).

THIS PROJECT WILL DESIGN AND TEST THE USE OF A NOVEL FLUORINATED ANION EXCHANGE SORBENT TO REMOVE PFAS COMPOUNDS FROM WATER.  THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY WILL IMPROVE UPON EXISTING ADSORPTION TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS ACTIVATED CARBON AND ANION EXCHANGE RESINS WHICH ARE NOT SPECIFIC FOR PERFLUOROALKYL COMPOUNDS. THIS DESIGN WILL PUBLIC HEALTH THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF CONTAMINANTS LINKED TO INCREASED RISKS IN CANCER, OBESITY, AND IMMUNE SUPPRESSION. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THE PROJECT WILL STUDY THE USE OF PHYCOREMEDIATION TO REMOVE WATER POLLUTANTS FROM STORMWATER PONDS AND TREATMENT WETLANDS. HARVESTED ALGAE WILL BE ALSO STUDIED AS A POTENTIAL MEDIUM FOR USE IN VERMICOMPOSTING. THIS RESEARCH HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BE AN EASILY IMPLEMENTED, LOW-COST, SUSTAINABLE PRACTICE TO MINIMIZE THE RELEASE OF AQUATIC POLLUTANTS, SUCH AS MERCURY AND NUTRIENTS THAT IMPACT ECOSYSTEMS AND PUBLIC HEALTH. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER).

THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE THE DEGRADATION AND REMOVAL MECHANISMS USING TWO MODEL POLYFLUOROALKLYL SUBSTANCES (PFASS) WITH A REACTIVE ELECTROCHEMICAL MEMBRANE (REM) FILTRATION. THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HOLISTICALLY EXAMINE HOW TO INCREASE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PFAS REMOVAL AND IMPROVE CONVENTIONAL WATER OR WASTEWATER TREATMENT PROCESSES. SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL ADVANCE POINT-OF-USE (POU) APPLICATIONS FOR RESIDENTIAL AND SMALL COMMUNITIES RESULTING IN IMPROVED WATER QUALITY AND HUMAN HEALTH PROTECTION. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A NOVEL PROCESS TO CONTROL AND MITIGATE HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS) BASED ON REACTIVE NANOBUBBLE TECHNOLOGY.  NANOBUBBLE TECHNOLOGY IS BEING SUCCESSFULLY USED IN OTHER APPLICATIONS BUT IS LARGELY UNEXPLORED AND NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD FOR USE IN WATER PURIFICATION.  THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE UNIQUE CHARACTERISTICS OF NANOBUBBLE TECHNOLOGY AND HOW IT CAN BE USED TO CONTROL AND DECREASE THE OCCURRENCE OF FRESHWATER HABS THEREBY IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND DRINKING WATER SECURITY. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL DESIGN AND FABRICATE A LOW-COST SMART WATER MONITORING DEVICE, NEEDED BECAUSE LEAD CONTAMINATION IS A CLOSE-TO-HOME PROBLEM CAUSED BY CORRODED LEAD SERVICE PIPES CONNECTING HOUSEHOLDS TO MAIN LINES OR LEAD-BASED PLUMBING. IT WILL IDENTIFY AND MEASURE LEAD LEVELS AT THE TAP IN REAL TIME AND ISSUE ALERTS. PROVIDING PERVASIVE REAL-TIME MONITORING OF LEAD LEVELS IN DRINKING WATER WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE PREVENTION OF LEAD POISONING AND ITS ADVERSE HEALTH EFFECTS, PARTICULARLY ON VULNERABLE YOUNG CHILDREN AND INFANTS. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A DRINKING WATER TREATMENT MATERIAL CONTAINING A MAGNETIC SUPPORT AND AN ACTIVE BIOCOMPONENT THAT CAN SELECTIVELY REMOVE TOXIC HEAVY METALS, INCLUDING ARSENITE, FROM WATER.  THE NANOCOMPOSITES BEING DEVELOPED WILL BE EFFICIENT FOR REMOVAL OF ARSENITE AND INEXPENSIVE TO USE. THEY WILL BE SUITABLE FOR SMALL, RURAL, TRIBAL AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES WHERE TRADITIONAL WATER TREATMENT TECHNOLOGIES ARE NOT APPROPRIATE. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP NEW ABSORPTION MATERIALS FOR THE REMOVAL OF PFOA AND PFOS FROM DRINKING WATER AND WASTEWATER. THE ADSORBENTS BEING DEVELOPED WILL HAVE A HIGHER ADSORPTION CAPACITY FOR PFOA AND PFOS AND SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE THEIR CONCENTRATIONS IN CONTAMINATED WATERS.  USING THE ADSORBENTS TO TREAT WATERS REDUCES CONTAMINATION IN THE ENVIRONMENT AND IMPROVES PUBLIC HEALTH BY REDUCING THE RATES OF ILLNESSES LINKED WITH EXPOSURE TO PFOA AND PFOS. (PROVIDE FOR CLEAN AND SAFE WATER)

THIS RESEARCH CONVERTS LARGE QUANTITIES OF AGRICULTURAL BIOMASS WASTE INTO BIOCHAR TO IMPROVE WATER RETENTION AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY.  THE TEAM IS COLLABORATING WITH LOCAL AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY AND COMMUNITIES TO CONVERT LARGE AMOUNTS OF AGRICULTURAL AND FOREST BIOMASS WASTE AND RESIDUE INTO BIOCHAR ON-SITE.

THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO STUDY PLANT-POLLINATOR INTERACTIONS THROUGH OUTREACH TO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND PROVIDE SCIENCE-BASED ADVICE TO LAND MANAGERS AND STATE AND LOCAL POLICY MAKERS FOR THE PURPOSE OF CROP IMPROVEMENT AND BIODIVERSITY.

THIS RESEARCH PROJECT REDUCES THE WATER CONSUMPTION OF CHEMICAL SCRUBBERS USED TO REDUCE AMMONIA EMISSIONS, WHILE ALSO MAXIMIZING THE ABILITY TO REDUCE AMMONIA EMISSIONS. THE TEAM HAS DESIGNED A THREE-STEP AMMONIA AIR SCRUBBING AND FILTRATION SYSTEM THAT REUSES WATER, RECYCLES WASTE, AND REDUCES COSTS. THIS TECHNOLOGY SUPPORTS MODERN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS. A COMPLETE INSTALLATION OF THE DESIGN IS SCHEDULED TO BE IMPLEMENTED AND TESTED AT THE SCOTT BROTHERS DAIRY FACILITY OVER THE NEXT TWO YEARS

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE, LOW-COST, AND EASY TO MAINTAIN FILTERS FROM A NOVEL SOURCE. THESE FILTERS ARE DESIGNED TO ABSORB POLLUTANTS FROM URBAN WATER RUNOFF WITH MINIMAL LEACHING. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO REMOVE NUMEROUS CONTAMINANTS FROM URBAN STORMWATER AT THE SOURCE, SHORTENING WATER TREATMENT TIME, AND INCREASING EFFICIENCY OF THE PROCESS.

THIS RESEARCH DEVELOPS A LOW COST TECHNOLOGY FOR PCB (POLY-CHLORINATED BIPHENYLS) DECONTAMINATION, WHICH REMAINS A CHALLENGING WORLDWIDE PROBLEM BECAUSE OF PCB'S HIGH TOXICITY AND BIO-ACCUMULATION. THE PROJECT IDENTIFIES THAT TOLUENE IS A BETTER SOLVENT THAN METHANOL AND STUDIES THE OPTIMUM CONDITIONS FOR CATALYTIC DECHLORINATION. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CHORINE POSITION VS. DECHLORINATION, AND THE REACTION KINETICS ON PCBS. THE RESULTING TECHNOLOGY SUPPORTS DECONTAMINATION OF SITES WHERE PCBS HAVE ACCUMULATED.

THIS PROJECT DEVEOPS A METHOD OF REPLACING POWER CABLES IN AIRCRAFTS WITH WIRELESS POWER TRANSFER SYSTEMS THAT ARE LIGHTER AND REDUCE THE WEIGHT OF THE PLANE. THIS REDUCTION FACTOR PER PLANE MULTIPLIED BY THE TOTAL NUMBER OF FLIGHTS IN THE WORLD, RESULTS IN A SUBSTANTIAL REDUCTION IN FUEL USED DURING FLIGHTS. THIS REDUCTION IN AIRCRAFT WEIGHT AND FUEL CONSUMTION WILL SUPPORT THE GOAL OF INPROVING AIR QUALITY, WHILE ALSO HAVING THE POTENTIAL TO SUPPORT THE AIRCRAFT INDUCTRY WITH MORE ENVIRONMENTAL EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGY AND PRACTICES RESULTING IN DECREASED EMISSIONS.

ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) IS USED TO REDUCE THE VOLUME OF FOOD WASTE SENT TO LANDFILLS WHILE ALSO CONVERTING THE WASTE INTO A USEFUL PRODUCT. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A MORE EFFICIENT AMMONIA REMOVAL AND RECOVERY PROCESS FOR FOOD WASTE DIGESTERS TO INCREASE THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC VALUE OF AN AD SYSTEM. THE NEW PROCESS WILL RESULT IN A COST EFFECTIVE SOIL AMENDMENT FOR AGRICULTURE SYSTEMS, AND WASTE REDUCTION IN LANDFILLS, AS WELL AS A DECREASE IN GAS THAT OCCURS WITH HIS CONCENTRATOINS IN LANDFILLS.

THIS PROJECT TESTS THE USE OF BIODIESEL WASTE GLYCEROL (DEVELOPED DURING PHASE I OF THE PROJECT) IN THE PRODUCTION OF A SERIES OF DEEP EUTECTIC SOLVENTS. THE PROJECT FOCUSES ON RESEARCHING HOW GLYCEROL CAN BE AN ALTERNATIVE TO CONVENTIONAL VOLATILE ORGANIC SOLVENTS, AND THE POTENTIAL OF USE IN CAMPUS LABORATORIES. BY DEVELOPING A SAFE AND SUSTAINABLE SOLVENT, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP DISPOSE OF INDUSTRY WASTE GLYCEROL AND REUSE A TRADITIONAL WASTE PRODUCT EFFECTIVELY.

THIS PROJECT DEVELOPS A SOLAR COLLECTOR THAT IS ABLE TO USE SOLAR HEAT AND NIGHT SKY COOLING TO ACCOMPLISH HEAT AND COLD COLLECTION. THIS COLLECTOR RETAINS THE FUNCTIONALITY OF A CONVENTIONAL GLAZED FLAT PLATE SOLAR COLLECTOR FOR HEAT COLLECTION, BUT  ALSO HAS AN ADDITIONAL ABILITY FOR COLD COLLECTION WITH ENHANCED EFFICIENCY AND COST-EFFECTIVENESS COMPARED WITH UNGLAZED COLLECTORS. WORKING WITH INDUSTRY ON THE DESIGN, THE RESULTING PRODUCT COULD REPLACE COOLING TOWERS AND SUPPORT WATER AND ENERGY CONSERVATION.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE A MORE ENERGY EFFICIENT WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEM THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO OKLAHOMA AND OTHER STATES.  THE PROPOSED SYSTEM WILL USE LESS ENERGY WHILE ALSO PRODUCING LESS POLLUTED DISCHARGE, LEADING TO CLEANER WATER WAYS AND LESS EMISSIONS FROM OVERUSE OF ENERGY.

THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO PROVIDE AN ECOFRIENDLY AND RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCE THAT SUPPORTS ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. THE RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCE THEY ARE USING IS BIOFUEL, WHICH HAS THE POTENTIAL FOR COMMERCIALIZATION. BY PROVIDING AN ALTERNATIVE RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCE, THIS TECHNOLOGY CAN HELP DETER HARMFUL POLLUTANTS FROM TRADITIONAL ENERGY SOURCES AND SUPPORTS ENERGY INDEPENDENCE.

THIS TEAM IS CREATING AN INEXPENSIVE CATALYTIC CONVERTER TO USE ON DEVICES SUCH AS LAWN MOWERS, LEAF BLOWERS, AND GAS POWERED GENERATORS THAT WILL REDUCE EMISSIONS OF CARBON MONOXIDE, NITROGEN OXIDE, PARTICULATE MATTER, AND VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS. THIS TECHNOLOGY AIMS TO REDUCE HARMFUL EMISSIONS FROM SMALL ENGINES AND PRODUCE BETTER AIR QUALITY.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE A HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEM THAT PRODUCES RENEWABLE FERTILIZER FROM SEAFOOD WASTES. THIS TECHNOLOGY CAN PROVIDE AN ADDED REVENUE STREAM FOR FARMERS AND WILL REDUCE THE ARMOUNT OF WASTE BEING LANDFILLED. THE GREEN FERTILIZER PRODUCED FROM THIS TECHNOLOGY CAN HELP THE AGRICULTURAL ECONOMY AND CURBS THE NEED FOR SENDING SEAFOOD WASTE TO LANDFILLS.

THIS TEAM AIMS TO BETTER SEPARATE COMPONENTS WITHIN BATTERIES TO AID IN WASTE REDUCTION AND RECYCLING. THEIR TECHNOLOGY IS LOW-ENERGY AND COST-EFFICIENT. THIS TECHNOLOGY CAN MINIMIZE HAZARDOUS WASTE STREAMS AND LEAD TO CLEANER LAND. IT WILL ALSO HELP PRESERVE AND RECOVER PRECIOUS MATERIALS WITHIN BATTERIES.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EFFECTIVELY TREAT PETROLEUM REFINERY WASTEWATER AND RECOVER A BROAD SPECTRUM OF NUTRIENTS IN AN AFFORDABLE WAY, WHICH IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUSTAINABLE WATER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THE PROJECT WILL DESIGN, TEST, AND EVALUATE A PROPOSED SYSTEM THAT CONVERTS WASTEWATER TO BIOPLASTICS, WHICH CAN BE USED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR PETROLEUM-BASED PRODUCTS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN CLEANER WASTEWATER DISCHARGE AND REDUCTIONS OF HAZARDOUS WASTE DISCHARGE FROM PETROLUEM REFINERIES. PROVIDE CLEAN AND SAFE WATER

THIS PROJECT IS USING GREEN CHEMISTRY TO DEVELOP AN ADDITIVE THAT CAN IMPROVE THE OVERALL EFFICIENCY OF SOLAR DISINFECTION TECHNIQUES FOR DRINKING WATER PURIFICATION. MANY HOMES USE SOLAR DISINFECTION AS AN IN-HOME WATER TREATMENT SYSTEM. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CREATE A MORE EFFICIENT SOLAR WATER TREATMENT TECHNIQUE THROUGH GREEN CHEMISTRY.

THIS PROJECT DEVELOPS GUIDELINES FOR ARCHITECTS AND ENGINEERS TO ENSURE ADEQUATE INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (IEQ) ALONG WITH PROVIDING MEASURES FOR REDUCING ENERGY CONSUMPTION IN THE OPERATION OF GREEN BUILDINGS. THE COMPLETION OF THE PROGRAM WILL ENSURE IMPROVED INDOOR AIR QUALITY IN OPERATING GREEN BUILDINGS WITH ALIGNS WITH THE ADMINISTRATOR'S GOAL TO IMPROVE AIR QUALITY MANAGEMENT IN FEDERAL BUILDING, WHICH WILL IMPROVE WORK CONDITIONS AND REDUCE COSTS OF OPERATIONS.

THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY IS TO CREATE A UNIQUE WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEM THAT IS ALSO ABLE TO PRODUCE ALGAL BIOFILM, WHICH CAN BE USED AS FEEDSTOCK FOR ENERGY GENERATION.  THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TWO-FOLD; TO CREATE A MORE EFFECTIVE AND COST-EFFICIENT WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEM AND USE THE OUTPUT OF THAT SYSTEM AS THE FEEDSTOCK FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY PRODUCTION.

SOLAR DISINFECTION, OR SODIS, IS A HOUSEHOLD WATER TREATMENT TECHNIQUE PROVEN TO REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF WATERBORNE DISEASE. A LOW-COST REUSABLE SODIS SENSOR WOULD PROVIDE USERS WITH VISUAL CONFIRMATION THAT THEIR DRINKING WATER HAS RECEIVED SUFFICIENT SUNLIGHT FOR PURIFICATION. THE DEVELOPMENT OF A REUSABLE DYE-BASED SODIS SENSOR WILL PROVIDE AN ECONOMICALLY VIABLE SOLUTION THAT IS CURRENTLY UNAVAILABLE. THIS RESEARCH WILL DEVELOP AN IN-HOME SENSOR THAT CAN ALERT USERS TO THE SAFETY OF THEIR DRINKING WATER.

THIS TEAM IS PLANNING TO USE NANOTECHNOLOGY IN WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEMS TO MAKE THEM MORE EFFECTIVE IN DETECTING AND REMOVING DIFFICULT TO TREAT CONTAMINANTS. THEIR TECHNOLOGY USES GRAPHENE BEADS TO MAKE WASTE WATER TREATMENT PLANTS MORE EFFECTIVE AND PROVIDE CLEANER DRINKING WATER.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DESIGN AN INNOVATIVE POWER GENERATION WELL PROTOTYPE THAT WILL HELP INCREASE THERMAL RECOVERY EFFICIENCY THROUGH CONVERSION OF THERMAL ENERGY TO ELECTRICITY, RESULTING IN A BETTER FACILITY ENVIRONMENT AND SAFER OPERATIONS. THIS DESIGN WILL ALSO ENHANCE THE ECONOMIC COMPETITIVENESS OF GEOTHERMAL ENERGY FOR LARGE-SCALE UTILIZATION, AND CAN CAPITALIZE ON EXISTING OR ABANDONED NATURAL GAS/PETROLEUM RECOVERY WELLS. A GEOTHERMAL ENERGY PRODUCTION SYSTEM WILL REDUCE AIR POLLUTION AND RESULT IN CLEANER AIR QUALITY.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A SENSOR THAT ENABLES ONLINE MONITORING AND CONTROL OF THE PHOSPHORUS REMOVAL PROCESS. THE SENSOR WILL PROVIDE RELIABLE AND ACCURATE REAL-TIME MEASUREMENTS OF PHOSPHATE IN WASTEWATER AND WILL SIMPLIFY OPERATIONS, INCREASING REMOVAL/RECOVERY EFFICIENCIES AND REDUCING CHEMICAL USAGE AT WASTEWATER FACILITIES. THE SENSORS DEVELOPED THROUGH THIS PROJECT ALLOW FOR BETTER NUTRIENT RECOVERY IN WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANTS AND COST REDUCTIONS IN RUNNING THESE PLANTS.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CREATE A LIGHTWEIGHT, FLEXIBLE, THIN FILM SOLAR PANEL THAT HAS APPLICATIONS BEYOND JUST BUILDING ROOFTOPS. THIS WILL INCREASE SOLAR POWER GENERATION CAPACITY AND IMPROVE ENERGY EFFICIENCY. BY CREATING A MORE FUNCTIONAL SOLAR PANEL THAT CAN BE USED ON MULTIPLE SURFACES, THIS TECHNOLOGY CAN INCREASE SOLAR POWER GENERATION, WHILE REDUCING EMISSIONS FROM CONVENTIONAL ENERGY SOURCES AND WILL ALSO REDUCE COSTS OF INSTALLING TRADITIONAL SOLAR PANELS THAT ARE FRAGILE AND HEAVY.

THIS TEAM CREATED A CLEAN ALTERNATIVE TO DIESEL FUEL AND IS DETERMING ITS PERFORMANCE WITH COMPRESSION IGNITION ENGINES.  THE FUEL BLEND CREATED CAN BE BENEFICIAL TO THE ENGINE INDUSTRY IN THAT IT REDUCES TIME AND COST FOR RESEARCH AND DESIGN OF A NEW ENGINE SYSTEM THAT ACCOMODATES THIS CLEANER FUEL LEADING TO CLEANER AIR.

SEPTIC SYSTEM FAILURE CAN LEAD TO HEALTH ISSUES WITHIN CHILDREN AND OTHER VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AS THE WATER COMES INTO CONTACT WITH GROUND AND SURFACE WATER. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO INNOVATE CURRENT CONVENTIONAL SEPTIC SYSTEMS TO MAKE THEM SAFER AND LESS PRONE TO FAILURE.  THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN CLEANER ONSITE WASTEWATER TREAMENT FOR AMERICAN HOMES, PARTICULARLY THOSE IN RURAL COMMUNITIES.

THIS PROJECT ASSISTS DECISION-MAKERS TO CONSIDERING NEW LOCAL RESOURCES FOR ADDRESSING GLOBAL FOOD INSECURITY. THE TEAM IS DEVELOPING A SYSTEM POWERED BY SOLAR AND HYDROENERGY FOR STORAGING HARVESTED GRAINS DURING RAINY SEASONS IN RURAL REGIONS OF AFRICA.  THIS SYSTEM CAN BE IMPLEMENTED IN DOMESTIC RURAL AREAS FACING SIMILAR SITUATIONS DURING HARVEST SEASON. GRAIN PROCESSING CAN BE AN ENVIRONMENTALLY TAXING PROCEDURE AND THIS NEW STORAGE SYSTEM CAN IMPROVE AIR QUALITY BY REDUCING THE GAS EMISSIONS TYPICALLY RELEASED DURING CONVENTIONAL GRAIN PROCESSING.

THE TEAM IS DEVELOPING AN OPEN-SOURCE GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) BASED DECISION SUPPORT AND DESIGN TOOL. THE TOOL WILL BE USED TO DESIGN GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS SUCH AS RAIN GARDENS AND PERMEABLE PAVEMENTS, AND VEGETATED SWALES THAT DELIVER ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS FOR SMALL WATERSHEDS IN URBAN ENVIRONMENTS.  BY MAKING THE DESIGN OPEN-SOURCE, THIS PROJECT CAN HELP RURAL COMMUNITIES THAT MAY NOT HAVE ACCESS TO GIS SYSTEMS AND DESIGNS. THE TEAM PLANS TO INCORPORATE WORKING WITH LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS ON THE BENEFITS OF GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP TECHNOLOGY TO HARNESS WIND ENERGY FOR IMPROVED AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS THROUGH EFFICIENT DRYING TO CURB CONTAMINATION FROM AFLATOXIN, A CONTAMINATE IN SEED CROPS LINKED TO SEVERE HEALTH IMPACTS.  ALSO, A WIND TURBINE WILL BE DESIGNED TO GENERATE FORCED AIR IN A SOLAR DRYER OR LOCAL STORAGE BIN, INCREASING RATE OF HEAT TRANSFER AND MOISTURE REMOVAL DURING DRYING.

THIS PROJECT INTEGRATES CAMPUS WASTE PRODUCTS INTO RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES, MAKING LOYOLA UNIVERSITY CHICAGO A ZERO-WASTE AND CARBON-NEUTRAL URBAN CAMPUS BY REDIRECTING WASTE FROM CAFETERIA FOOD PRODUCTION, WETLAND RESTORATION, AND BIODIESEL PRODUCTION.THE PROJECT FOCUSES ON URBAN CAMPUSES AND REDIRECTING WASTE STREAMS TO PRODUCE A CARBON NEUTRAL CAMPUS BY PRODUCING ENERGY FOR HEATING AND ELECTRICITY FROM ORGANIC WASTE. SOIL THAT USES BIOWASTE WILL RESTORE WETLANDS, REDUCING WASTES SENT TO LANDFILLS OR WASTE WATER TREATMENT PLANTS.

THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY USES BEETLES AS A WAY TO DEGRADE STYROFOAM WASTES. THE BEETLES CAN THEN ALSO BE USED AS ANIMAL FEED AND AS AN ADDITIVE TO COMPOST MIXES.  THIS TECHNOLOGY WILL RESULT IN LESS STYROFAM GOING TO LANDFILLS AND ALSO AID THE AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY IN BEING ABLE TO PROVIDE FEED AND COMPOST ADDITIVES.

THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE FUNDAMENTAL OBJECTIVE OF SOLVING REAL WORLD GREEN BUILDING BASED DECISION-MAKING ACROSS MULTIPLE AREAS SUCH AS ENERGY USAGE, COST EFFICIENCY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE COMPUTER MODELING SYSTEMS THAT CAN MAKE BUILDINGS MORE ENERGY EFFICIENT AND CONSERVE RESOURCES. THIS RESEARCH CAN BE USED IN RETROFITTING CURRENT BUILDINGS AND ALSO IS HELPFUL IN CONSTRUCTION OF NEW BUILDINGS.

THIS TEAM PLANS ON SAVING ENERGY WITHIN BUILDINGS BY CREATING A LIGHT CONTROL SYSTEM THAT IS ABLE TO DRAW INFORMATION FROM HUMAN REACTIONS (LIKE THE SIZE OF EYE PUPILS). THE TECHNOLOGY WILL RESULT IN LESS ENERGY USE, WHICH IN TURNS PRODUCES LESS TOXIC AIR POLLUTANTS. IT WILL ALSO LEAD TO BETTER BUILDING DESIGNS IN THE FUTURE.

THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE AN IN-HOME SMART FEEDBACK DEVICE THAT CAN FACILITATE RESPONSIBLE WATER USUAGE. THE DEVICE WILL PROVIDE UPDATES ON WATER USUAGE AND AIMS TO CAUSE BEHAVIORAL CHANGES IN THE USER IN ORDER TO IMPLEMENT WATER CONSERVING PRACTICES. AS AN IN-HOME DEVICE, THIS TECHNOLOGY CAN BE USED TO CONSERVE WATER IN AMERICAN HOUSEHOLDS AND ALSO EDUCATE USERS ON WATER CONSERVATION PRACTICES. (PROVIDE CLEAN AND SAFE WATER, PRIORITIZE ROBUST SCIENCE).
THIS PROJECT ALTERS THE WASTE STREAM OF CLOTHING AND CAN REDUCE THE MILLIONS OF POUNDS OF CLOTHING THAT IS SENT TO LANDFILLS EVERY YEAR.

THE TEAM IS DEVELOPING A PILOT SCALE UPFLOW ANAEROBIC SLUDGE BLANKET (UASB) REACTOR THAT IMPROVES THE ACCESSIBILITY OF WASTEWATER TREATMENT FOR SMALL COMMUNITIES. EFFECTIVE MUNICIPAL WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEMS TYPICALLY EXIST AS LARGE, CENTRALIZED URBAN SYSTEMS. THESE SYSTEMS ARE NOT APPROPRIATE FOR APPLICATIONS IN DEVELOPING NATIONS, AS THE HIGH FIXED COST OF CONSTRUCTION MAKES WASTEWATER TREATMENT UNAFFORDABLE FOR SMALLER VILLAGES.  THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE WASTEWATER SYSTEMS AND IMPLEMENT THE TECHNOLOGY IN LOCAL COMMUNITIES FIRST.

THIS TEAM IS DESIGNING AND DEVELOPING A LOW-COST HOUSEHOLD WATER FILTER USING BIOCHAR THAT WILL REMOVE LEAD FROM DRINKING WATER.  THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CLEANER DRINKING WATER FOR HOMES USING A HOUSEHOLD WATER TREATMENT SYSTEM.

THIS TEAM IS DESIGNING A SYSTEM THAT USES BIOFILTRATION TECHNOLOGY AND AN IN GROUND DETENTION TANK TO TREAT GRAY WATER PRODUCED IN HOUSEHOLD'S TO BE USED FOR OUTDOOR APPLICATION, NAMELY IRRIGATION. DESIGNING A SYSTEM THAT USES THE GRAY WATER ALREADY PRODUCED IN DAILY HOUSEHOLD ACTIVITIES FOR THE USE OF IRRIGATION HAS THE CAPABILITY OF DECREASING THE DEMAND FOR TREATED WATER.  THE SYSTEM'S BENEFITS COULD INCLUDE A REDUCTION OF DOMESTIC WATER CONSUMPTION, CONSERVING WATER AND ENERGY RESOURCES, AND DECREASING DEMAND OF WATER FROM NATURAL RESERVOIRS.

THIS TEAM PROJECT AIM IS TO MORE EFFICIENTLY RECOVER NUTRIENTS FROM URINE. THE RECOVERED NUTRIENTS CAN BE USED IN THE AGRICULTURAL FIELD AS ADDITIVES TO FERTILZERS. THROUGH THIS TECHNOLOGY, THERE IS LESS NUTRIENT WASTE IN WATERWAYS AND THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY BENEFITS FROM THE RECOVERED NUTRIENTS.
THIS TECHNOLOGY PROPOSES TO CURB WATER POLLUTION BY CREATING AN OIL-WATER SEPARATOR.  THIS TECHNOLOGY WILL LEAD TO CLEANER SURFACE WATER AND CAN BE USED FOR OIL SPILL REMEDIATION.

IN PHASE I THE PROJECT USED ANHYDROUS ETHANOL AND ACTIVATED CARBON TO BUILD A BENCH-SCALE SOLAR THERMAL ABSORPTIVE REFRIGERATOR THAT ACHIEVED COOLING AT TEMPERATURES OF 2 ' 8 DEGREES CENTIGRADE.  A LIFE CYCLE ANALYSIS SHOWED SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS COMPARED WITH A CONVENTIONAL REFRIGERATOR.  IN PHASE II THE PROJECT WILL SCALE UP THE REFRIGERATOR, TEST AZEOTROPIC ETHANOL AS A REFRIGERANT, EVALUATE ALTERNATIVE SOURCES OF ACTIVATED CARBON, AND PERFORM LIFE CYCLE ANALYSES COMPARING THE EFFECTS OF USING THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF ETHANOL AND ACTIVATED CARBON.

THE OBJECT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE THE HEAT FROM A COOKING FIRE TO GENERATE ELECTRICITY.  TO DO THIS THE PROJECT WILL DESIGN, BUILD, AND TEST THERMOELECTRIC GENERATORS THAT CAN BE MANUFACTURED USING LOCAL MATERIALS IN MALAWI.  THE GENERATOR WILL PRODUCE ENOUGH POWER TO CHARGE A PHONE OR AN LED LIGHT.  THE PROJECT WILL ALSO DEVELOP AN INEXPENSIVE ELECTRONIC PACKAGE TO CONVERT THE VOLTAGE OUTPUT FROM THE GENERATOR TO STANDARD USB 5-VOLT OUTPUT.

PHASE I SHOWED THAT FIBER-PLASTIC COMPOSITE BOARDS USING RECYCLED POLYETHYLENE PLASTIC AND MILLED RICE HUSKS PRODUCED STRONG, STIFF, LIGHTWEIGHT, TERMITE-RESISTANT BOARDS THAT COULD REPLACE PLYWOOD PARTICLE BOARDS IN DISASTER-RELIEF HOME CONSTRUCTION IN THE PHILIPPINES.  IN PHASE II THE PROJECT WILL OPTIMIZE AT BENCH-SCALE BOARD PERFORMANCE, SCALE UP THE SIZE OF THE BOARDS, WORK WITH THE INTERNATIONAL DEAF EDUCATION ASSOCIATION TO USE THE BOARDS IN HOME CONSTRUCTION, AND BEGIN LOCAL MANUFACTURE OF THE BOARDS.

IN PHASE I THE PROJECT PRODUCED 3-D PRINTED BIOFILTRATION MEDIA THAT OUT-PERFORMED CURRENTLY-USED MEDIA IN REMOVING NITROGEN FROM FISHERIES EFFLUENT.  IN PHASE II THE PROJECT WILL SEEK TO MAXIMIZE THE SURFACE AREA OF THE MEDIA, CHARACTERIZE THE CONDITIONS THAT WILL MAXIMIZE BIOFILM GROWTH ON THE MEDIA, AND DO LIFE CYCLE ASSESSMENTS OF MOVING BED AND TRICKLING BIOFILTERS IN ORDER TO PRODUCE GREEN GUIDELINES" FOR BIOFILTRATION MEDIA DESIGN.
PHASE I SHOWED THAT POLYALUMINUM CHLORIDE (PACL)-PRECIPITATED FLUORIDE CAN BE REMOVED BY SAND FILTRATION AND PACL CAN BE ADDED AS A COAGULANT IN A CO

IN PHASE I THE PROJECT DEVELOPED A PROTOTYPE OF A MICRO-ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL (MEC) SYSTEM CONSISTING OF A WEARABLE MODULE, A CENTRAL CONTROL MODULE, AND AN OUTDOOR WEATHER MODULE INTENDED TO INCREASE BOTH INDOOR ENERGY USE EFFICIENCY AND PERSONAL COMFORT.  THE OBJECTIVES OF PHASE II ARE TO IMPROVE THE PERFORMANCE OF THE SYSTEM COMPONENTS AND TO TEST THE MEC AT A RETIREMENT COMMUNITY.

THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY THE PRACTICALITY OF USING STORMWATER BIOFILTRATION TO SLOW RUNOFF AND CAPTURE POLLUTANTS, USING THE CITY OF CHICO AND CSU CHICO CAMPUS AS TEST BEDS.  THE PROJECT WILL DO LABORATORY STUDIES TO DETERMINE KEY DESIGN PARAMETERS TO ACHIEVE BIOFILTER RESILIENCY AND MONITOR FOR 18 MONTHS THE HYDROLOGIC AND POLLUTANT REMOVAL OF THE EXISTING BIOFILTERS IN THE TEST BEDS.  IT WILL DEVELOP A METHODOLOGY FOR DETERMINING THE MOST EFFECTIVE MEDIA-PLANT COMBINATIONS FOR BIOFILTRATION SYSTEMS IN PARTICULAR SETTINGS.  THE RESULTS WILL BE SYNTHESIZED IN A GUIDANCE DOCUMENT.
